item.title: Pathfinder: Kingmaker Sales Officially Reach the 2m Mark
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/pathfinder-kingmaker-sales-2m

Publisher Knights Peak and developer Owlcat Games have announced that their CRPG Pathfinder: Kingmaker has hit a brand new sales milestone over six years after its initial launch.

Per a press release, Pathfinder: Kingmaker sales have now hit the two million mark. It seems the milestone may have been reached a little too late for the game's sixth anniversary, which fell in September last year, but it's still an achievement for Owlcat and Knights Peak to be proud of.

At last count, Owlcat's followup Pathfinder: Wrath of the Righteous had reached a million sales, and earlier this week, the studio revealed that its grimdark futuristic CRPG Warhammer 40k: Rogue Trader had hit the same number. That puts Kingmaker out in front as the studio's best-selling game to date.

It does mean that the game is trailing behind genre rivals like Baldur's Gate 3, but given that Owlcat's games are arguably much more niche than Larian's big hit, that's probably not a big surprise.

If you're not familiar with Pathfinder: Kingmaker, it's a CRPG that serves as both Owlcat Games' first title and the first video game to be set in the Pathfinder world. The game sees you building and managing your very own kingdom, navigating courtly intrigue and seeing off threats to your rule as you do so.

As you'd probably expect from a modern CRPG, the game lets you create your own hero and meet a range of diverse companions, as well as iconic figures from the Pathfinder mythology. It also allows you to choose between real-time and turn-based combat depending on your personal preference, which is always nice.

Pathfinder: Kingmaker is available right now on PC, PlayStation 4, and Xbox One, and you can also play it on current-gen consoles thanks to the magic of backwards compatibility. Stay tuned for more on all other things Owlcat.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: It Looks Like Major Dragon Age: The Veilguard Updates Are Ending With Patch 5
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/dragon-age-the-veilguard-updates-ending-patch-5

EA has released a new patch for Dragon Age: The Veilguard, and judging by the wording in the official patch notes, this looks to be the game's final major update.

In a post on the official Veilguard website, EA says it was "so happy with the game's stability at launch" and that the game is now "in a stable place". As such, the development team is now "moving to monitor for any game-breaking bugs", which rather sounds like there won't be any more significant content updates.

This patch isn't exactly massive, either; it doesn't add any new quests or content, but brings more quality-of-life changes, like recommended levels being added for lower-level quests and a number of bug fixes as well.

I'm speculating a little here, but it also sounds a bit like Veilguard won't be getting any major expansions like previous Dragon Age games did, so if you're expecting this game's version of Awakening or even DLC packs like Trespasser, you might want to save your disappointment now.

While the wording of the post seems to suggest EA and BioWare want to put a positive spin on ending updates for Dragon Age: The Veilguard, the fact remains that the game sold disappointingly for the company, coming in at around half of EA's expectations for the quarter in which it released.

Along with EA Sports FC 25, Veilguard's underperformance caused EA to adjust its financial expectations for the 2024-25 fiscal year, which in turn led to a drop in the company's stock value of almost 20%. Yeowch.

It's also worth noting that Dragon Age: The Veilguard director Corinne Busche departed BioWare recently, and while her departure isn't necessarily related to the game's underperformance, the timing of the two announcements seems a touch too coincidental for them not to be connected.

In any case, Dragon Age: The Veilguard is available right now for PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S, and Patch 5 is out now. You can read our very own Erren's review of the game right here.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
